value: caption=Old Capitol dome in Iowa City

is a city of just over 60,000 people in
. It is primarily known as the home of the University of Iowa.
Iowa City was the first capital of the state of Iowa, before the capital was moved westward to

. Considered a college town, many jobs are associated with the university and its teaching hospital.  Other large employers include educational service companies ACT and Pearson.  It is widely recognized as one of the most educated cities in the United States.

According to the U.S. Census Bureau, Iowa City has a population of about 68,000 (2010). The university has an enrollment of approximately 30,000 students.  As such, the university has a strong effect on the culture of Iowa City and affects the community in a variety of ways, including the hospital and various university teams and programs.

Also influential in the community is the university's Writer's Workshop, which caused Iowa City to be named the third UNESCO City of Literature, so far the only such city in North America.

Coralville is an adjacent community located to the west of Iowa City, and its largest suburb, with a population of over 18,000.

value: http://www.iowacitycoralville.org/ Iowa City/Coralville Area Convention and Visitors Bureau

value: content=Service to Iowa City from Chicago, Des Moines, and Omaha. The bus stop is located on the east side of S Dubuque Street just north of E Court Street.
Greyhound and Burlington Trailways offer bus service to a variety of cities, mostly ones along Interstate 80.

Walking is the easiest way to get around downtown Iowa City; the university is right in the middle of downtown. For greater distances, there is an extensive bus system ($0.75/ride). The university's Cambus system covers most of the campus buildings and is free and open to the public.

value: content=Tour Iowa's first capitol building in the center of the Pentacrest. Also visit the Discovery Center and the Humanities Gallery. Gift shop.
name=University of Iowa Museum of Art
content= Some European paintings, large collection of African art, changing exhibitions. Gift shop, coffee bar.
name=University of Iowa Museum of Natural History
directions=inside MacBride Hall at the corner of Jefferson and Clinton Sts
content=Displays of Iowa's geology and ecology, as well as Native American culture. Features a reconstruction of a giant Ice Age sloth and a large collection of birds. Gift shop.
name=University of Iowa Athletics Hall of Fame
price=$4 adults, $3 students, seniors, free under 12
content=Displays about the history of the Hawkeye teams, including Nile Kinnick's Heisman Trophy.
content=Over 70 automobiles dating from 1899, a replica of an early Skelly gas station, and a model train display.

: A sometimes cited unusual attraction, the Black Angel is a statue in Oakland Cemetery (north Governor Street).  Designed by famed sculptor Mario Korbel, the statue is 8.5 feet tall and depicts a dark angel of death guarding over a grave.  The beautiful, yet eerie angel has been a source of local urban legend since its construction.  Many legends say that if anyone kisses the statue, he or she will be struck dead unless they are a virgin.  Despite this, the Angel and her folklore have been embraced.  A miniature replica has even been erected on the Pedmall.
offer beaches, camping, hiking, and boating.
Twenty minutes west of Iowa City on Highway 6 lies
, another popular camping destination with a small lake and beach.
content=A historic theatre, first opened in 1912, now operates as a stage for plays, comedy and music performances, and community events.  Also home to a small gallery showcasing local artwork.

content=Iowa City's resident professional theatre presents both classic and contemporary theatre.  Most popular are Shakespeare plays, which are performed each summer at City Park's Shakespeare Theater.
content=Student-operated independent theatre in the Memorial Union is the only theatre in the area showing independent, art-house, and foreign films.
content=Iowa City's most popular music venue offers performances by local, regional, and national bands and musicians. Some all ages shows but mostly 19+.
content=Both a restaurant and a venue for live music, The Mill is home to performances by local and regional musicians. Every Monday is open mic night. Almost all shows 19+.
alt=formerly The Q and The Industry
content=Bar and live music venue, with local and national music acts.  Most shows 19+.
content= Live jazz groups, both local and from around the world play on stages set up around downtown Iowa City.

content=First weekend in June.  Popular three-day community celebration of local and regional artists, including open admission to downtown's art galleries, live music, local food vendors, and other activities.
address=On the wall at the Pentacrest on the corner of Jefferson and Clinton Sts
content=A new sand sculpture competition in which teams work with professional sand sculptors and architects to create large sand sculptures.  Live music and activities for children.
price=$115 for All Access pass, $60 for limited passes
content=Nationally-known acts, indie bands, and local musicians perform at various venues downtown. Literary readings by authors at local bookstores and coffee shops.
content=An independent film festival with film screenings, panels, and filmmaking workshops taking place at three downtown venues.
hours=Three times yearly (March, May, and October), F 5-8
content=20 downtown galleries showcase the works of local and regional artists.
address=City Park and downtown Iowa City
content=Day in June.  Gay pride parade, run, and festival.
, Iowa's first university, founded in 1847, UI is a large, public university that offers over 100 programs of study and has a student body of over 30,000 students.

content=This large bookstore downtown frequently appears on "Top 10 Bookstores in the U.S." lists. It features regular readings by nationally and internationally known authors.

content= The place to go to get a taste of anything you've been craving.

content=Local Mexican fast-food chain offering made-to-order burritos and quesadillas.

Because of the university, downtown is very busy on weekend nights.  With thousands of college-aged people (and older folks staying around for home games) drinking within a few blocks of each other, use caution when walking to or visiting establishments.  There is a bar for all types. State law requires alcohol purchases to be made before 2AM. After 10PM non-exempt drinking establishments only allow persons 21 years of age and older, unless accompanied by a parent, guardian, spouse or domestic partner.

value: content= Due to the large cover for those yet to turn 21 years of age, it caters to an older crowd.  There's a dance floor and it's pretty upbeat.
content=  Classy place. Great wine and cuisine.
gay bar and dance club. DJs most nights of the week, plus fun drag shows, karaoke, theme parties and contests. Mainly college-aged(19+).

content=  A staple bar for decades. It's known for incredible pizza ($1.50/slice on Sundays) and cheap drinks. Visited by Tom Brokaw in May 2008 when his favorite booth as a student was dedicated to him with a plaque.
content= Located downtown and generally caters to an older crowd.  Fairly laid-back atmosphere.
alt=formerly The Q and The Industry
content=Good place to play pool and get cheap beer.  Draws a fairly diverse crowd and has great music with frequent shows upstairs.

content=A dark dive bar, not a buffet. However, they do make the best burgers in Iowa City.  Filled with locals and students from the Writers' Workshop.  If you go in the afternoon, you'll probably spot more than one aspiring writer filling up a notebook.
alt=everyone just calls it The Fox Head

content=One block away from George's.  Often considered the "fiction bar," to George's supposed allegiance within the poetry division.  Inreality, students from each of the disciplines frequent both locations.  Divey, with a popular pool table, a jukebox, and a taxidermied fox behind the bar.
content=Variety of cheap drinks.  Great place to watch football and basketball games.  It gets pretty chaotic on the weekends.
content=Wings and beer, busier on game day.
content=New, modern, hotel downtown on the Pedestrian Mall, in Iowa City's tallest building.
content=Large new hotel and conference center in Coralville, with river views.

content=Located on the campus of the University of Iowa, Sheraton Iowa City features wireless Internet, an indoor heated pool, a fitness center and is 100% smoke-free. All 234 guest rooms include the Sheraton Sweet Sleeper bedding, Starbucks coffee and 37-inch flat panel televisions.

name=Herbert Hoover Presidential Library and Museum
directions=I-80 east to exit 254, north on Parkside

content=Located 15 minutes east of Iowa City.  Exhibits about the life of former President Herbert Hoover and temporary exhibits about American history and culture.  Tours of Hoover's birthsite cottage, a blacksmith shop, a Quaker meeting house, and the Hoovers' gravesite.  Gift shop.
